bestBHT.bht: As the world shakes, people will faint out of fear. The word used for fainting originally means to leave off breathing or to swoon. This is exemplified by the description of Hector being dragged behind Achilles' chariot, where he breathed out his life. This conveys the intense fear and distress that will be experienced. The anticipation of the impending events adds to the intensity, as men's hearts fail them. The phrase the world refers to the inhabited earth, underscoring the widespread impact of this shaking.

Marvin Vincent: The word originally means to leave off breathing; to swoon.
So also Sophocles, of Hector dragged behind Achilles' chariot: 'He breathed out his life.'"
Archibald T. Robertson: Men fainting (αποψυχοντων ανθρωπων). Genitive absolute of αποψυχω, to expire, to breathe off or out. Old word. Here only in N.T."
Expectation (προσδοκιας). Old word from προσδοκαω, to look for or towards. In the N.T. only here and Acts 12:11."
The world (τη οικουμενη). Dative case, 'the inhabited' (earth, γη).
John Gill: Men's hearts failing them for fear...
and for looking after those things which are coming on the earth...
for the powers of heaven shall be shaken...

bhtAttempts.bht: In Luke 21:26, it is said that men will faint out of fear as the world shakes. The word used for fainting originally means to leave off breathing or to swoon, like when Hector was dragged behind Achilles' chariot and 'breathed out his life.' This signifies the magnitude of the fear and distress that will be experienced. The expectation or anticipation of the events to come adds to the intensity, as men's hearts fail them. The phrase 'the world' refers to the inhabited earth, which emphasizes that this shaking will affect all of humanity.

In this verse, it is mentioned that people will faint due to fear as the world shakes. The word used for fainting originally means to leave off breathing or to swoon. This is similar to when Hector was dragged behind Achilles' chariot and breathed out his life. It signifies the immense fear and distress that will be experienced. The expectation or anticipation of the events to come adds to the intensity, as men's hearts fail them. The phrase the world refers to the inhabited earth, highlighting that this shaking will impact all of humanity.

This is exemplified by the description of Hector being dragged behind Achilles' chariot, where he breathed out his life. This conveys the intense fear and distress that will be experienced. The anticipation of the impending events adds to the intensity, as men's hearts fail them. The phrase the world refers to the inhabited earth, underscoring the widespread impact of this shaking.

In Luke 21:26, it is foretold that the world will be shaken and men will faint due to fear. The word used for fainting means to leave off breathing or to swoon, like Hector when he breathed out his life while being dragged behind Achilles' chariot. As the anticipation of these events grows, men's hearts fail them. This shaking will have a significant impact, affecting the inhabited earth. Therefore, this verse emphasizes the overwhelming fear and distress that will be experienced by all.

When the world shakes, people will faint in fear. The word used for fainting means to leave off breathing, like when Hector breathed out his life while being dragged behind Achilles' chariot. This signifies the immense fear and distress that will be experienced. The anticipation of these events adds to the intensity, as men's hearts fail them. The world refers to the inhabited earth, highlighting the widespread impact of this shaking on humanity.
